context: <b3_0>Theologus Autodidactus<b3_0/>, written by the Arabian polymath <b4_0>Ibn al-Nafis<b4_0/> (<a0_0>1213–1288<a0_0/>), is the first example of a <a1_0>science fiction<a1_0/> novel. It deals with various science fiction elements such as <b5_0>spontaneous generation, futurology, the end of the world and doomsday, resurrection, and the afterlife<b5_0/>. Rather than giving supernatural or mythological explanations for these events, Ibn al-Nafis attempted to explain these plot elements using the <a2_0>scientific knowledge<a2_0/> of biology, astronomy, cosmology and geology known in his time. <b6_0>Ibn al-Nafis<b6_0/>' fiction explained Islamic religious teachings via science and Islamic philosophy.
